feature: Baseline (pre-action) (occurrence ~t=0–40): stable negative offset (values typically ~-0.6 to -1.3 depending on sample). Morphology: low-variance, slowly varying baseline with small low-amplitude bulges in some samples (e.g., small valley around t~15–25 in Samples 1, 3, 5). Time-frequency: weak energy concentrated at the 0Hz row and immediately adjacent low-frequency rows (indicates DC/slow bias). Heatmap mapping: generally neutral-to-weakly red (small positive SHAP) or near-zero in some samples — interpreted as mildly typical or background-supporting features for the label (not strongly discriminative).

Pre-raise small valley/jitter (occurrence ~t=10–30 in some samples): small transient valley or bulge before the main rise (amplitude ~0.1–0.4 relative units). Time-frequency: weak, slightly broader low-frequency content (0Hz + adjacent rows). Heatmap mapping: sometimes slightly red (Sample 1, Sample 5) indicating the model treats this small pre-movement as modestly typical; in other samples this region is near-neutral in SHAP (ambiguous).

Rapid rising transition (occurrence ~t=40–65 across samples): steep upward slope (large positive first derivative) where hand moves from baseline up to raised position. Morphology: sharp monotonic increase over ~10–25 time steps; amplitude increase from baseline (~-1) to plateau (~+1.0 to +1.8). Time-frequency: concentrated high energy at the lowest frequency rows (0Hz row and immediate adjacent low frequencies) with sometimes a small spread into slightly higher low-frequency components (indicating a fast low-frequency transient rather than high-frequency jitter). Heatmap mapping: predominantly red at the 0Hz row and adjacent low-frequency rows in this time window for most samples (Samples 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) — interpreted as a typical, highly discriminative feature for label 0 (drawing/raising action). In a couple of samples there is a small presence of blue at adjacent low-frequency rows concurrent with the rise (Sample 2 and Sample 4 show small blue patches), indicating slight model confusion or that some specific spectral content of the transition is atypical in those cases.

Raised/hold plateau (occurrence ~t=55–95 depending on sample): sustained positive amplitude (stable hold) with low variance during the one-second point/aim pose. Morphology: flat or gently varying plateau; amplitude range typically +1.0 to +1.8 depending on sample. Time-frequency: strong, concentrated energy dominated by the 0Hz row (a DC/low-frequency component consistent with a maintained offset) and little energy in high-frequency bands. Heatmap mapping: strongly red on the 0Hz row for the central plateau time windows in most samples (Samples 1, 2, 3, 5 show clear red dominance at low freq/time). This indicates the model treats sustained elevated hand position as a core, typical feature of the 'gun-draw' label. In Sample 4 the plateau region remains generally red at low frequencies but also shows some scattered weak blue in higher low-frequency rows (slight ambiguity).

Rapid falling transition (occurrence ~t=95–115 across samples): steep negative slope returning from plateau to baseline. Morphology: sharp decline over ~10–20 time steps; amplitude drop back to negative baseline. Time-frequency: elevated energy again concentrated at 0Hz and adjacent low frequencies; in some samples a bit more spread into intermediate rows indicating small post-motion oscillation. Heatmap mapping: often red at the 0Hz row in the falling window indicating typical feature (the model expects a return motion). However, Sample 4 shows a noticeable blue patch near the falling transition (strong negative SHAP around t~75–95 in some low-frequency rows) indicating that certain spectral characteristics of the fall in that sample are atypical and may slightly contradict the canonical pattern.

Post-action baseline (occurrence ~t=110–149): return to negative baseline similar to pre-action. Morphology: low variance, often slight additional small dips/peaks late (small negative bulge near t~135–145 in Samples 1, 3, 5). Time-frequency: weak, concentrated at 0Hz and immediate rows. Heatmap mapping: mostly neutral or slightly red at low-frequency rows in several samples; meaning the stable return-to-baseline is generally typical but not as discriminative as the rise/plateau.

Localized higher-frequency/energy spread (occurrence sporadic in rising/falling windows for some samples): in a few samples (e.g., Sample 2 during the rise) there is slightly broader energy distribution across adjacent low-frequency rows (wider vertical spread in STFT). Morphology in the line: small jitter or quicker micro-oscillations riding on top of the slope. Heatmap mapping: this broader spread sometimes corresponds to a mix of red and blue — model finds core low-frequency DC energy typical but the extra spread (micro-jitters) ambiguous or atypical (blue in Sample 2 and Sample 4 in localized cells).
pattern: Sample 21 (Sample 1): Early stage baseline stable negative (~t=0–40) (low-frequency, near-DC energy) (heatmap: weak-to-neutral red) + Rapid rising transition (~t=40–55) (steep rise from ~-1 to ~+1.2) (low-frequency 0Hz strong energy) (heatmap: strong red at 0Hz → interpreted as typical raising feature) + Plateau (~t=55–95) (sustained positive ~+1.2) (0Hz dominant energy) (heatmap: strong red → typical hold feature) + Falling transition (~t=95–115) (steep decline to baseline) (low-frequency energy) (heatmap: moderate red → typical) + Post baseline (~t=115–149) (small negative bulge) (heatmap: neutral).

Sample 2: Baseline negative and stable (~t=0–50) (heatmap: neutral) + Rapid rise beginning slightly later (~t=50–70) to a higher plateau (~+1.7) (strong 0Hz energy) (heatmap: red concentrated at 0Hz for rise and plateau → typical) + Notable localized atypical spectral spread during mid-rise (~t=60–75) where adjacent low-frequency rows show some blue in SHAP (this indicates the model flags some of the spectral content of this rise as less typical or possibly similar to other labels) + Falling (~t=95–110) back to baseline (0Hz energy; heatmap: mixture but primarily red at plateau and rise).

Sample 9 (Sample 3): Pre-action baseline (~t=0–40) slightly more negative (~-1.2) with small pre-rise bump at ~t=20 (heatmap: mostly neutral) + Rise (~t=40–60) (fast slope to ~+1.1) (STFT: concentrated at 0Hz) (heatmap: red at 0Hz → typical) + Long plateau (~t=60–95) (steady high) (heatmap: red dominant at 0Hz → typical) + Fall (~t=95–115) returning to baseline with small late negative dip (~t=135–145) (heatmap: weak red/neutral).

Sample 46 (Sample 4): Baseline (~t=0–45) negative and stable (heatmap: neutral) + Rise (~t=50–70) to a high plateau (~+1.8) (0Hz energy; heatmap: red at rise and plateau) + Notable atypical region: during the late plateau/early fall (~t=75–95) there is a localized blue (negative SHAP) patch at low-frequency rows — morphology: a small departure in spectral signature during fall (small oscillatory component or different slope) that the model treats as atypical (possibly indicates this sample's fall differs from canonical pattern) + Final fall (~t=95–115) and return baseline (heatmap: mixed but the unusual earlier blue indicates partial atypicality).

Sample 41 (Sample 5): Baseline negative with early small valley (~t=10–30) (heatmap: weak red/neutral) + Rise (~t=40–60) to plateau (~t=60–95, amplitude ~+1.2) (strong 0Hz energy; heatmap: pronounced red at low-frequency rows during rise and plateau → typical) + Fall (~t=95–115) returning to negative baseline with a late negative bulge (~t=140) (heatmap: mostly neutral-to-red at key low-frequency times).

feature: Sample 1 (index 0): Baseline (time 0–~52): negative stable baseline around -0.65 to -0.7, very low amplitude variability. STFT shows very low energy (mostly at the 0Hz row). Heatmap: weak neutral-to-blue coloring on the baseline region => interpreted as not a typical positive label-driving feature (atypical/neutral). Rapid rise / onset (time ~52–70): fast positive slope from ~-0.7 up to ~1.6–1.9, large amplitude change (~2.5 absolute difference). STFT: strong energy concentrated in the 0Hz (DC/very-low-frequency) row and adjacent low-frequency rows during the rise. Heatmap: strong red on the low-frequency rows and time window covering the rise and early plateau => this rise is a typical feature. Sustained plateau (time ~70–95): stable high positive values ~1.7–1.9 (low intra-plateau volatility). STFT: continued concentrated low-frequency energy. Heatmap: red dominance in low-frequency rows during plateau => plateau is a typical feature. Descent/return (time ~95–110): relatively fast fall back to baseline (~1.9 down to -0.8), STFT energy at low frequencies; heatmap shows weaker or mixed coloring with small blue areas at adjacent low-frequency bins => classified as ambiguous to slightly atypical (the model sometimes treats return as not strongly typical for this label). Post-return baseline (time ~110–149): negative stable baseline ~-0.8 with small jitter; STFT low energy; heatmap near-neutral/blue => atypical or neutral.

Sample 2 (index 4): Baseline (time 0–~48): negative stable baseline ~-0.6 to -0.65, low energy in STFT at low freq; heatmap: small red/neutral patches early but mostly neutral => baseline not strongly typical. Rise onset (time ~48–66): steep increase from ~-0.5 to ~2.05, large amplitude and steep slope. STFT: strong very-low-frequency energy concentrated at 0Hz row and neighboring rows. Heatmap: mixed but with red centered on the rise/early plateau low-frequency bins => rise considered a typical feature. Plateau (time ~66–80): high stable values ~2.0–2.06 with minimal jitter, STFT strong DC energy; heatmap: red in low-frequency rows => typical. Post-plateau drop (time ~80–110): fall back to slightly negative (-0.5 to -0.6) with a small rebound around ~110, STFT shows energy during the fall and small higher-frequency content at rebound; heatmap: blue markings appear around the early mid-rise/just-before-rise low-frequency bins and some blue during return => parts of the transition and return are treated as atypical or confusing by the model.

Sample 3 (index 8): Baseline (time 0–~24): stable negative baseline around -1.05 to -1.12; STFT: low energy at DC; heatmap: neutral-to-slight-red at some low frequencies early (weak) => baseline neutral. Rapid onset (time ~24–35): sharp rise from -1.1 to +1.05 (large magnitude change), STFT: concentrated low-frequency energy but also small spread into adjacent frequency rows indicating slight transient jitter. Heatmap: strong red concentrated at the very-low-frequency rows during the onset (typical). Plateau (time ~35–95): sustained positive ~1.03–1.05 with low volatility; STFT: DC energy; heatmap: mild positive/red contribution for plateau but weaker than the onset in this sample => plateau is typical but model emphasizes the onset. Descent (time ~95–110): sharp fall back to ~-1.1; STFT low-frequency energy, some higher-frequency content in the descent (small jitter); heatmap: blue/negative markings in descent low-frequency rows => descent considered atypical for the label (model flags it as more characteristic of other labels). Late trough & recovery (time ~110–149): steady negative baseline near -1.08 to -0.95 with tiny ripples; heatmap neutral or slightly blue => atypical/neutral.

Sample 4 (index 36): Baseline (time 0–~30): negative baseline ~-1.3 to -1.2 with small noise; STFT low energy; heatmap: neutral-to-slight-red in low-frequency rows early (weak) => baseline not decisive. Onset/rise (time ~30–40): fast rise from ~-1.2 to ~1.0, STFT: concentrated DC/very-low-frequency energy; heatmap: clear red in the 0Hz and adjacent rows for the rise window => rise is a typical positive-label feature. Sustained plateau (time ~40–~105): long stable positive region ~0.9–1.0 (moderate amplitude compared to other samples), STFT strong low-frequency energy. Heatmap: the plateau low-frequency region shows red and some neutral areas => plateau treated as typical. Descent (time ~105–125): rapid fall back to ~-1.2 with pronounced change; STFT energy and some spread into higher rows around the fall. Heatmap: blue/negative in low-frequency rows over the descent window => descent is an atypical feature (model associates this pattern more with other labels). Post-descent baseline (time ~125–149): negative stable baseline ~-1.15 with small noise; heatmap largely neutral.

Sample 5 (index 38): Baseline (time 0–~24): deep negative baseline ~-1.6 to -1.55, STFT shows elevated DC energy due to strong negative offset; heatmap: small neutral-to-red patches early but mostly neutral => baseline not decisive. Onset (time ~24–40): fast rise from -1.6 to ~0.6, STFT large DC energy and some adjacent rows (slight transient jitter). Heatmap: strong red in the early onset low-frequency bins => onset typical. Long plateau (time ~40–~130): sustained positive around 0.6–0.7 with low volatility (long duration). STFT: concentrated at 0Hz row with some low-frequency harmonics. Heatmap: parts of the plateau (especially onset and some late plateau windows) are red (typical), but there are also small blue patches at select low-frequency bins mid-plateau => some portions of plateau are ambiguous to the model (mixture of typical and slightly atypical). Sharp descent (time ~130–149): large negative movement down to ~-1.8, STFT energy concentrated at low freq and some adjacent rows. Heatmap: red markings reappear near the descent in some low-frequency rows (in this sample the descent is partly treated as a positive contribution) and blue in other bins => descent is mixed: partially typical (model sees informative energy) and partially ambiguous/atypical depending on frequency row.
pattern: Sample 1 pattern: Pre-onset negative baseline (0–52) (stable ~-0.7) (heatmap blue/neutral => atypical/neutral) + Sharp rise (52–70) (large positive slope, amplitude -0.7 up to ~1.9) (low-frequency energy at 0Hz and adjacent rows; heatmap strong red => TYPICAL) + Sustained plateau (70–95) (stable high ~1.7–1.9) (low-frequency DC energy; heatmap red => TYPICAL) + Descent/return (95–110) (fast fall back to baseline) (low-frequency energy; heatmap mixed/blue => ambiguous/atypical).

Sample 2 pattern: Baseline (0–48) (stable -0.6) (heatmap neutral => not decisive) + Onset (48–66) (very steep rise to ~2.05) (strong 0Hz energy; heatmap red concentrated on rise => TYPICAL) + Peak plateau (66–80) (very high stable ~2.0) (DC energy; heatmap red => TYPICAL) + Return & small rebound (80–110) (fall and small rebound) (STFT shows return energy and small higher-frequency content; heatmap shows blue in transition windows => return atypical/confusing).

Sample 3 pattern: Baseline (0–24) (stable ~-1.1) (heatmap neutral) + Rapid onset (24–35) (large magnitude increase to ~1.05) (strong DC and slight spread to adjacent freq rows indicating transient; heatmap red on onset => TYPICAL) + Long plateau (35–95) (stable ~1.03) (DC energy; heatmap mildly red => TYPICAL but less emphasized) + Sharp descent (95–110) (drop to ~-1.1) (low-frequency energy and some higher-frequency distribution; heatmap blue => ATYPICAL) + Late baseline (110–149) (steady negative baseline) (heatmap neutral/blue).

Sample 4 pattern: Baseline (0–30) (stable ~-1.3) (heatmap neutral) + Onset/rise (30–40) (fast large rise to ~1.0) (DC-dominated energy; heatmap red => TYPICAL) + Long plateau (40–105) (stable positive ~0.9–1.0) (DC energy; heatmap red/neutral => TYPICAL) + Descent (105–125) (fast fall to ~-1.2) (low-frequency energy; heatmap blue/negative => ATYPICAL) + Recovery baseline (125–149) (stable negative).

Sample 5 pattern: Baseline (0–24) (deep negative ~-1.6) (heatmap neutral) + Onset (24–40) (rise to ~0.6) (strong DC energy plus adjacent rows; heatmap strong red at onset => TYPICAL) + Prolonged plateau (40–130) (stable moderate positive ~0.6–0.7) (DC energy; heatmap red in onset and parts, but contains small blue patches mid-plateau => mostly TYPICAL with some ambiguous windows) + Sharp descent (130–149) (drop to ~-1.8) (low-frequency energy with mixed heatmap red/blue across different rows => mixed: partially typical in some freq rows but atypical in others).

feature: Baseline steady negative offset (type: baseline) — occurrence: early phase (time steps ~0–50) — manifestation: values around -0.6 to -0.8, small slow trend or micro-bulges before the rise; stability: low variance but with small local bulges/jitters around t≈30–45 — heatmap mapping: low-frequency rows (0Hz and adjacent) show blue/weak-white contributions in this time region in several samples (atypical feature).

Pre-rise small valley / downward bulge (type: valley) — occurrence: just before the main rise (time steps ~40–55) — manifestation: a small decrease or local valley of amplitude ~-0.55 to -0.75, sometimes a small notch prior to the steep ascent (morphology: brief dip) — heatmap mapping: marked blue on low-frequency rows (dominant blue at 0Hz) in SHAP heatmaps in many samples (atypical), meaning the model treats this pre-rise notch as evidence against the gun class.

Rise onset slope variability (type: other - slope/change) — occurrence: rise phase start (time steps ~50–70) — manifestation: slope ranges from gradual to steep across samples; some samples show a very sharp rapid rise, others a slightly more gradual ascent; amplitude change: baseline to plateau ~1.5–2.0 — heatmap mapping: mid/low-frequency rows during the rise show mixed red/blue; the strong, clean rapid rise appears red (typical) while a more gradual/irregular rise shows mixed or blue markings (ambiguous / atypical depending on sample).

Sustained mid-phase plateau / main peak (type: peak) — occurrence: mid phase (time steps ~60–95) — manifestation: sustained high values (peak plateau) with amplitude approx 1.6–1.95 and low internal volatility (morphology: flat-top plateau lasting ~20–40 steps) — heatmap mapping: consistently red concentrated in the lowest frequency row(s) (0Hz and immediate neighbors) and sometimes light-red in adjacent low-frequency rows; this is treated as a typical gun-draw feature by the model.

Mid-phase low-frequency energy spread (type: other - frequency content) — occurrence: mid-phase plateau (time steps ~60–95) — manifestation: STFT shows concentrated energy in the 0Hz (very low) bin and adjacent low-frequency bins (morphology: tight low-freq energy band) — heatmap mapping: these low-frequency components are red (positive SHAP), indicating the model recognizes the sustained plateau energy as typical for the gun label.

Descent / return-to-baseline slope and secondary bumps (type: slope/other) — occurrence: late phase (time steps ~95–130) — manifestation: main descent from plateau back to baseline; some samples show a clean descent, others show small secondary positive/negative bumps or slight oscillations (amplitude of these bumps ~0.05–0.2) at times ~108–125 — heatmap mapping: these descent irregularities are often blue (atypical) in the low-frequency rows and sometimes in slightly higher frequency rows (model treats secondary bumps/irregular return as atypical and contributing to misclassification).

Post-return baseline offset and small jitter (type: baseline/other) — occurrence: very late phase (time steps ~120–149) — manifestation: baseline returns to around -0.6 to -0.8 but with tiny oscillations or a slight drift; occasional small bumps near t≈120–135 — heatmap mapping: low-frequency SHAP often light-blue or white here (weak negative contribution or ambiguous), making the final baseline region sometimes atypical for the gun class.

Higher-frequency minor components during transitions (type: other - jitter/high-freq) — occurrence: around transitions (rise onset ~50–70 and descent ~95–115) — manifestation: small jitters or higher-frequency content visible in STFT as slightly broader frequency spread for very short times; amplitude small but present — heatmap mapping: these appear as faint blue/white in adjacent higher frequency rows (ambiguous/atypical); when present they reduce the model's confidence in the gun class.

Early baseline steady negative offset (occurrence: t ≈ 0–45). Manifestation: values centered around -0.55 to -0.65 with very low variance and small slow micro-bulges (tiny local upward bumps) particularly around t ≈ 20–40. Heatmap mapping: mostly very light-red / near-zero contributions across many frequency rows but with localized light-blue at the lowest frequency (0 Hz) near t ≈ 30–45 in some adjacent cells. Interpretation: baseline is nominally a typical gun-draw baseline (low variance, negative offset) but the small localized low-frequency blue marking near t ≈ 30–45 makes this baseline slightly atypical for the gun class in the model's eyes.

Pre-rise small valley / downward notch (occurrence: t ≈ 40–55, immediately before the main ascent). Manifestation: a brief local dip/notch below the baseline then a rapid turn-up; amplitude change relative to baseline ≈ -0.05 to -0.15; morphology: short-duration valley/notch that precedes the major rise. Heatmap mapping: strongly blue concentrated in the lowest frequency row (0 Hz) and very light-blue in adjacent low-frequency rows during t ≈ 40–55. Interpretation: the model treats this pre-rise notch as an atypical feature for the gun class and as evidence leaning toward the pointing class.

Rise onset and slope (occurrence: t ≈ 50–70). Manifestation: a fairly steep, mostly monotonic ascent from baseline to plateau. Amplitude change ≈ 2.3 units (from ≈ -0.6 to ≈ +1.7–1.95); rate: relatively sharp (over ~15–20 time steps). Heatmap mapping: dominant red in the lowest-frequency row(s) across the rise window; however low-level mixed blue/red pixels appear in adjacent frequency rows for a few time steps when the slope is irregular. Interpretation: the steep, clean rise is regarded as a typical (positive/red) gun feature but the brief mixed-frequency irregularities at onset reduce its unambiguous contribution.

Sustained mid-phase plateau / main peak (occurrence: t ≈ 60–90). Manifestation: flat-top plateau with amplitude ≈ 1.75–1.95, very low volatility inside plateau (small micro-oscillations only). Time duration ≈ 25–35 steps. Time-frequency: concentrated energy strictly at the lowest-frequency band (0 Hz) and immediate neighbors. Heatmap mapping: strong red concentrated at 0 Hz and nearby low-frequency rows in the t ≈ 60–90 window. Interpretation: this is the strongest typical gun-draw cue and the model attributes the largest positive SHAP weight to this region.

Descent / return-to-baseline (occurrence: t ≈ 90–115). Manifestation: major downward slope returning signal from ≈ +1.9 to ≈ -0.6 over ≈ 20–25 steps; primarily smooth but contains a small secondary positive bump/oscillation near t ≈ 108–112 (amplitude ≈ 0.05–0.2). Time-frequency: main descent energy in very low frequencies but the secondary bump injects limited higher-frequency content at its local time. Heatmap mapping: the main descent is weakly red/neutral in low-frequency rows, while the secondary bump region shows blue in 0 Hz and light-blue in some higher rows. Interpretation: the small secondary bump is treated as atypical and reduces net positive evidence for the gun class.

Post-return baseline drift and small jitter (occurrence: t ≈ 115–149). Manifestation: returns to near-original negative baseline (~ -0.6 to -0.75) but with a slight downward drift and a small sustained negative excursion around t ≈ 118–125 (a little deeper than original baseline). Heatmap mapping: light-blue / near-zero in low-frequency rows across this late segment. Interpretation: this late drift/jitter is a minor atypical signature that weakly penalizes the gun prediction.

High-frequency transient energy at transitions (occurrence: concentrated near t ≈ 50–70 and t ≈ 100–115). Manifestation: brief, small-amplitude higher-frequency components visible in STFT as slight broadening of frequency support around transitions. Heatmap mapping: faint blue/white in adjacent higher-frequency rows during transition windows. Interpretation: these small high-frequency components create ambiguity and modestly subtract from gun evidence.

Early baseline steady negative offset (baseline) — occurrence: t ≈ 0–50. Manifestation: values centered roughly between -0.75 and -0.60 with very low variance; there are small slow micro-bulges (tiny upward bumps) especially around t ≈ 20–40. Heatmap mapping: the lowest-frequency row (0 Hz) and immediate neighbors show weak-to-light-blue contributions around t ≈ 25–40 and mostly neutral/light-red elsewhere in the early window. Interpretation: nominally a typical gun baseline (stable negative offset) but the localized low-frequency light-blue marks make this baseline slightly atypical in the model’s view (weak penalty).

Pre-rise small valley / downward notch (valley) — occurrence: t ≈ 45–55 (immediately before main ascent). Manifestation: a brief local dip/notch slightly below the ongoing baseline (amplitude change relative to baseline ≈ -0.05 to -0.15) that turns rapidly into the steep ascent. Time-frequency: modest energy but concentrated at very low frequencies in STFT. Heatmap mapping: strongly blue concentrated on the 0 Hz row in the pre-rise window (deep blue pixels). Interpretation: a clear atypical feature for the gun class; this region is judged by the model as evidence toward the pointing class and is a major negative contributor.

Rise onset slope and variability (other - slope/change) — occurrence: t ≈ 54–70. Manifestation: a steep, mostly monotonic ascent from baseline up to the plateau over ~12–18 time steps (amplitude change ≈ 2.3 units from ≈ -0.6 to ≈ +1.7/1.8). STFT: concentrated low-frequency energy during the sharp slope, some limited spread to adjacent low-frequency rows when the slope is slightly irregular. Heatmap mapping: dominant red in the 0 Hz row through the rise window, but some adjacent low-frequency rows show mixed red/blue pixels at the earliest rise steps. Interpretation: overall this is a typical positive gun feature (strongly supportive), though small mixed-frequency pixels at the onset slightly reduce its unambiguous positive effect.

Sustained mid-phase plateau / main peak (peak) — occurrence: t ≈ 60–90. Manifestation: a flat-top plateau with amplitude ≈ +1.65 to +1.85 lasting ≈ 25–35 steps and very low internal volatility. STFT: concentrated energy tightly at the 0 Hz bin and immediate neighbors (very low-frequency content). Heatmap mapping: strong red concentrated at 0 Hz across the plateau window, weaker red in adjacent low-frequency rows. Interpretation: the model treats this as the canonical, highly positive gun-draw signature; it contributes the largest positive SHAP weight.

Descent / return-to-baseline slope and tiny transition higher-frequency content (slope/other) — occurrence: t ≈ 90–108. Manifestation: smooth descent from plateau back to baseline crossing the zero line near t ≈ 98–100, overall amplitude decrease from ≈ +1.8 to ≈ -0.6 over ~18 steps. STFT: main energy remains low-frequency but there is a slight broadening at the moment of descent producing faint higher-frequency components. Heatmap mapping: main descent region shows weak red/neutral at 0 Hz, while the short higher-frequency bleed is neutral-to-light-blue in adjacent rows. Interpretation: descent is mostly supportive/neutral for the gun label, but small higher-frequency components at the transition slightly subtract from confidence.

Late small secondary bump / post-descent small oscillation (other/valley-peak) — occurrence: t ≈ 108–125. Manifestation: a small oscillation or secondary bump during the return-to-baseline region; amplitude ≈ 0.05–0.2 relative to immediate surroundings (visible as a small positive bump then settling). STFT: localized, brief higher-frequency energy during the bump. Heatmap mapping: blue in the 0 Hz row and light-blue in some adjacent rows over this late interval. Interpretation: treated as atypical/negative by the model and reduces net positive evidence.

Post-return baseline drift and small jitter (baseline/other) — occurrence: t ≈ 120–149. Manifestation: return to a negative baseline near -0.6 to -0.8 with a slight downward drift and minor jitter; small long tail below baseline around t ≈ 120–135. Heatmap mapping: light-blue / near-zero at 0 Hz rows in late segment. Interpretation: weakly atypical and penalizes the gun score slightly.

High-frequency transient energy at transitions (other - jitter/high-freq) — occurrence: concentrated near t ≈ 54–70 (rise onset) and t ≈ 100–115 (descent/secondary bump). Manifestation: short-lived broader frequency spread in STFT (more frequency rows involved) indicating small jitters. Heatmap mapping: faint blue/white in adjacent higher-frequency rows during transition windows. Interpretation: these transients introduce ambiguity and modestly reduce the model’s gun confidence.
pattern: Sample 9 (ID: 9) pattern (True label = 0 'gun', Model predicted = 1 'no-gun/pointing', logits: [-0.1087, -0.0743]): Early phase baseline negative offset (~t=0–50; values ≈ -0.6 to -0.75) with a small pre-rise bulge/notch around t≈40–55 marked blue on the 0Hz row (atypical) + rapid steep rise and sustained mid-phase plateau t≈55–90 with amplitude ≈1.8–1.95, strong low-frequency energy (0Hz) marked red (typical) + descent t≈90–120 with smooth fall but small secondary bump near t≈110 that is blue in the SHAP (atypical). Net effect: typical central plateau is present (red) but atypical pre-rise valley and late small bump (blue) reduce the net SHAP support so the model crosses the decision boundary toward class 1.

Sample 10 (ID: 10) pattern (True label = 0 'gun', Model predicted = 1 'no-gun/pointing', logits: [-0.3573, 0.7666]): Baseline negative offset early (~t=0–40; values ≈ -0.8) with a pronounced micro-dip before the ascent (t≈40–55) shown as blue (strongly atypical) + rise and plateau (t≈55–100) amplitude ≈1.7–1.9 with concentrated low-frequency STFT energy red (typical) + relatively clean descent but weaker plateau flatness (slightly less uniformly flat) and minimal secondary noise. Because the early pre-rise atypical valley is strong (large blue SHAP) the model confidently predicts the pointing class despite a clear plateau.

Sample 42 (ID: 42) pattern (True label = 0 'gun', Model predicted = 1 'no-gun/pointing', logits: [-0.1760, 0.3007]): Early slow baseline (~t=0–50) with small pre-rise jitter and a slight negative notch (blue/ambiguous at low-frequency rows) + rise-to-plateau (t≈55–85) amplitude ≈1.65–1.8 with red low-frequency SHAP (typical) + descent (t≈90–115) somewhat gradual and clean but accompanied by weak higher-frequency components around transition (light-blue/ambiguous). The combination of mid-phase typicality plus pre/post transition atypical low-frequency signatures places this sample near the decision boundary and flipped the model prediction.

Sample 37 (ID: 37) pattern (True label = 0 'gun', Model predicted = 1 'no-gun/pointing', logits: [-0.0468, 0.1181]): Early baseline negative offset with several small bulges (~t=20–45) flagged blue in SHAP (atypical) + clear mid plateau (t≈55–95) strong red low-frequency energy (typical) + more evident scattered red/blue in middle-low adjacent frequencies (mixed signals) + late-phase small oscillations (t≈115–135) that are blue/negative in SHAP. The mixed red/blue in transition frequencies shows model confusion; the negative contributions around rise onset and return reduce the model's net confidence for the gun label leading to misclassification.

Sample 108 (ID: 108) pattern (True label = 0 'gun', Model predicted = 1 'no-gun/pointing', logits: [-0.0434, -0.0150]): Early baseline similar (~t=0–50 at ≈ -0.6) with a tiny pre-rise bulge and brief higher-frequency energy (small blue patches in SHAP) + sustained plateau (t≈55–90) amplitude ≈1.85–1.95 with strong 0Hz red (typical) + descent includes a small secondary bump around t≈115–125 producing higher-frequency energy and blue SHAP (atypical) + final baseline returns but with slight drift. Even though plateau is typical, the presence of atypical pre-rise and late secondary bump reduces the net positive SHAP so the model flips the decision on the boundary.

Pattern for Sample 9 (True label = 0 'gun', Model predicted = 1 'no-gun/pointing'; logits: [-0.1087, -0.0743]): Early-stage baseline (t ≈ 0–45) stable negative offset (~ -0.6) with tiny micro-bulges (heatmap: mostly neutral-to-light-red but localized low-frequency light-blue around t ≈ 30–45) (interpretation: weakly typical but with minor atypical cue) + Pre-rise small valley/notch (t ≈ 40–55) brief downward dip before the ascent (heatmap: strongly blue at 0 Hz — atypical) + Rapid rise onset and steep ascent (t ≈ 50–70) strong low-frequency energy (heatmap: red — typical) + Sustained flat plateau (t ≈ 60–90) high low-frequency concentration and strong red (typical, large positive contribution) + Descent back to baseline (t ≈ 90–115) mostly smooth but includes small secondary bump around t ≈ 108–112 that shows blue in low-frequency rows (atypical) + Final baseline with small downward drift and low-level jitter (t ≈ 115–149) light-blue / neutral (slightly atypical). Net effect: the single most damaging feature is the pronounced pre-rise notch (blue at 0 Hz) combined with a late secondary bump (blue) and small high-frequency transition energy that collectively reduce the summed SHAP support enough to move the model across the decision boundary toward the pointing class despite the strong mid-plateau red signal.

Boundary-character summary: The model treats the mid-plateau as the canonical gun-draw signature (strongly red), but even small atypical low-frequency events (pre-rise valley at t ≈ 40–55 and the secondary bump at t ≈ 108–112) produce disproportionately negative SHAP contributions. In Sample 9 these atypical low-frequency notches and transition high-frequency bleeds together outweigh the plateau's positive evidence just enough to flip the classification (logits near zero indicate a sample very close to the decision boundary). Therefore the classification-boundary pattern is: pronounced mid-plateau (typical/red) + localized pre-rise low-frequency valley (strongly atypical/blue) + late small bump/transition jitter (atypical/blue) = net shift to misclassification.

Pattern interpretation and boundary explanation (True label presumed = gun (0); Model predicted = 1 with logits [-0.1760, 0.3007]): The dominant structure is a textbook gun-draw waveform: stable negative baseline (t 0–50) + steep rise (t 54–70) + sustained flat plateau (t 60–90) + descent back to baseline (t 90–108). The plateau is strongly red in the SHAP heatmap (0 Hz low-frequency band) and yields the largest positive contribution. However, this strong canonical signature is counter-weighed by two localized atypical low-frequency events: (1) a pronounced pre-rise low-frequency notch (t ≈ 45–55) that is strongly blue at 0 Hz and (2) a late small secondary bump/oscillation during the return (t ≈ 108–125) that is also blue. Additionally, small mixed-frequency pixels at the rise onset and faint higher-frequency bleed at descent/transition further reduce net positive SHAP. Net effect: the large positive mass from the plateau is nearly balanced by negative SHAP contributions from the pre-rise notch and late bump together with transition jitter, moving the sample across the decision boundary toward the pointing class (resulting logits near zero and prediction = 1).

Which features create the classification boundary: The critical boundary-producing combination is: strong mid-plateau (typical, red, large positive) + localized pre-rise low-frequency valley (atypical, blue, large negative) + late small secondary bump/transition jitter (atypical/blue) + minor mixed-frequency irregularities at rise onset (ambiguous). The two atypical low-frequency events (pre-rise and post-descent) produce disproportionately negative SHAP contributions compared to their amplitude, and combined they outweigh enough plateau evidence to flip the model's decision.

Comparison to preliminary summary: The preliminary feature summary already identifies the same principal events (negative baseline with micro-bulges, pre-rise notch, steep rise and sustained plateau concentrated at 0 Hz, descent with secondary bump, late baseline drift and small high-frequency transition energy). Therefore the primary boundary features and the pattern causing misclassification for Sample 42 are already captured in the preliminary summary; the model’s confusion is explained by the strong plateau being counteracted by low-frequency atypical notches and late small oscillations that the model treats as pointing-like evidence.

Comprehensive sample analysis and boundary-pattern explanation (Sample ID 37). Summary: The sample presents a canonical gun-draw waveform in the central segment (steep ascent into a sustained plateau and a smooth descent back to baseline) but is accompanied by two small localized atypical low-frequency events (an early pre-rise low-frequency negative contribution and a late post-descent small oscillation). These atypical low-frequency events are marked blue in the SHAP heatmap and meaningfully subtract from the large positive contribution of the mid-plateau, pushing the model’s logits across the decision boundary toward the pointing class. This explanation is fully consistent with the preliminary feature summary; there are no omitted misclassification-causing features in the preliminary summary for this sample. Detailed stepwise evidence follows.

Early stage (t ≈ 0–45): baseline and pre-rise microfeatures
- Plot manifestation: The early segment is a steady negative baseline centered near roughly -0.7 to -0.6 with very low variance; small slow micro-bulges or tiny upward bumps are visible especially in the t ≈ 20–40 window. Immediately before the main rise, there is a modest deviation — a small local dip/irregularity/negative notch relative to the baseline that turns into the main ascent. Morphology: low-amplitude (≈0.05–0.15) local deviations, low volatility otherwise. 
- STFT mapping: low overall energy in early stage, with a modest low-frequency presence right before the rise. 
- SHAP/heatmap mapping: this pre-rise interval is marked blue (strongly negative SHAP) at the lowest-frequency row (0 Hz) and light-blue in adjacent low-frequency rows. Interpretation: the model treats the pre-rise notch and the localized low-frequency signature in this early period as atypical for the gun class (evidence toward pointing). This is a major negative contributor to the gun class score.

Rise and mid-stage plateau (t ≈ 50–95): the canonical gun feature
- Plot manifestation: A steep, mostly monotonic ascent begins near t ≈ 50 and reaches a sustained flat-top plateau roughly between t ≈ 60 and t ≈ 90. Amplitude change is large (from ≈ -0.6 baseline to ≈ +1.7–1.8 at plateau). Morphology: sharp slope over ≈12–20 time steps; plateau is broad and low volatility. 
- STFT mapping: concentrated energy tightly localized at the lowest-frequency bin (0 Hz) and immediate neighbors during plateau, indicating the sustained DC-like high segment. 
- SHAP/heatmap mapping: this central region is strongly red at 0 Hz (dominant positive SHAP), meaning the model recognizes the sustained plateau as the canonical supportive feature for the gun label. This region supplies the largest positive contribution to the gun score.

Late stage (t ≈ 95–149): descent and return baseline
- Plot manifestation: A smooth descent from the plateau returns the signal to near the original negative baseline around t ≈ 100–115. After return, there is a small secondary positive bump/oscillation around t ≈ 110–125 followed by a slightly drifting negative baseline with small jitter (t ≈ 120–149). Amplitude of the secondary bump is small (≈0.05–0.2 relative to immediate surroundings). 
- STFT mapping: the main descent shows low-frequency energy; the small secondary bump injects limited higher-frequency spread for a short time. 
- SHAP/heatmap mapping: the descent is near-neutral or weakly red at 0 Hz, but the late small oscillation and the post-return drift are marked blue (negative SHAP) in the 0 Hz row and light-blue in adjacent rows. Interpretation: the late bump is treated as atypical for gun and subtracts from the net positive evidence.

Boundary mechanics and model decision: why the sample is misclassified
- Net effect: the central plateau gives a large positive SHAP mass toward class 0 (gun). However, two localized atypical low-frequency events — (1) the pronounced pre-rise low-frequency notch (t ≈ 40–55) and (2) the late small secondary bump/oscillation during the return-to-baseline (t ≈ 108–125) — are strongly blue in the SHAP heatmap and provide disproportionately large negative contributions. Minor mixed-frequency bleed during the transitions also yields faint blue/white marks that increase ambiguity. The aggregated negative SHAP from these atypical events nearly cancels the strong plateau evidence, leaving model logits close to zero (logits: [-0.0468, 0.1181]) and producing a prediction of class 1 (pointing). The sample therefore sits very near the classification boundary.

Coverage relative to the preliminary feature summary: The preliminary summary already documents all of these elements for label 0 and explicitly includes Sample 37’s pattern (early micro-bulges and pre-rise notch, steep rise and sustained low-frequency plateau, descent and late small oscillations, and the SHAP interpretations). No additional misclassification-causing features or unexplained patterns are present beyond what the preliminary summary covers. Therefore there are no omissions to add for this sample.

feature: Baseline (early phase, ~t=0–45): stable negative offset around -0.6 to -0.7. Manifestation: low volatility, near-constant baseline before motion begins (small slow fluctuations ±0.02–0.05). Heatmap color: mostly light red at 0Hz-row and adjacent very-low-frequency rows in several samples (e.g., Samples 2,3,4,5 show clear red at early low-frequency bins). Interpretation: marked as a typical feature of label 1 (red → model regards this baseline as supporting the current label). This baseline itself is not the cause of misclassification but is a context feature the model expects for label 1.

Rapid rise (onset, ~t=45–60): sharp upward slope from baseline to peak. Manifestation: large positive first derivative localized in a ~10–20 time-step interval (fast rise), amplitude change approximately from -0.65 to +1.0–+2.3 (Δ ~1.6–3.0 depending on sample). Time-frequency: concentrated low-frequency energy but localized in time (large transient). Heatmap color: mixed—some low-frequency components show blue (atypical) in the rising window in Samples 1 and 3, while others show neutral/light red in Samples 2 and 5. Interpretation: when the rise is steeper and larger in amplitude the model marks parts of this rise as atypical (blue) — this contributes to pushing the prediction away from label 1.

Sustained plateau/hold (mid phase, ~t=60–90): prolonged high positive amplitude (the hand remains elevated). Manifestation: long-duration positive plateau with low within-plateau volatility; amplitude ranges between ~+1.5 and +2.3 (largest across samples). STFT: strong concentrated energy at the 0Hz row and immediate low-frequency rows (dominant low-frequency energy because the signal stays elevated). Heatmap color: predominantly blue in the plateau time region at the 0Hz and adjacent low-frequency rows for many samples (notably Samples 1 and 3 show clear blue around the plateau; Samples 2,4,5 show mixed but substantial blue). Interpretation: the sustained high-level plateau is treated by the black-box model as an atypical feature for label 1 (blue) — this is a primary driver of misclassification, since it resembles features of the other class (gun draw) in the model's learned representation.

Descent / crossing through zero (late mid-phase, ~t=90–105): downward slope back toward baseline producing a crossing of y=0. Manifestation: moderate to sharp negative slope; amplitude change from plateau (~+1.5–+2.0) down across 0 to negative. Heatmap color: mixed; some low-frequency bins near the descent are blue (Samples 1 and 3 show blue signals during descent), while several samples show slight red markings at the crossing or just after (Samples 2 and 5 show light red in some low-frequency bins around descent). Interpretation: when descent behaviour resembles the two-stroke motion (distinct draw and return) the model flags it as atypical for pointing (blue), increasing misclassification risk; mixed red/blue indicates model confusion in some samples.

Negative undershoot / return valley (late phase, ~t=100–125): small negative valley below baseline (amplitudes ~-0.6 to -1.0) after return. Manifestation: short-lived negative trough (undershoot) with slight local oscillation or small jitter. STFT: low-frequency energy during the trough plus small higher-frequency spread if jitter present. Heatmap color: generally light red at low-frequency rows for the trough in several samples (Samples 2 and 4 show low-frequency red near the valley) but tiny blue patches can appear if the trough is deeper or oscillatory. Interpretation: the undershoot is sometimes regarded as typical (red) but when deeper or accompanied by quick oscillation it may be marked atypical (blue); however this feature is not the primary misclassification cause.

Low-frequency dominance (time-frequency signature overall): across all samples the energy during the main event is concentrated at the 0Hz row and adjacent very-low-frequency rows (stable sustained elevation produces strong DC/very-low-frequency components). Manifestation: STFT panels show bright yellow/green at the 0Hz row during plateau (~t=55–95). Heatmap color: this same low-frequency region is often colored blue in the SHAP heatmaps for the plateau (Samples 1–5 show pronounced low-frequency SHAP coloration), indicating the model interprets this low-frequency, sustained energy during the mid-window as atypical for label 1 and more characteristic of the other class.

Absence of high-frequency jitter (morphology detail): plateaus and transitions are largely smooth; there is little broad, high-frequency spread in STFT. Manifestation: time-frequency images show narrow-band (low-frequency) energy rather than dispersed high-frequency bands. Heatmap color: because of the narrow-band low-frequency dominance the SHAP heatmaps focus on the 0Hz/very-low-freq rows; the lack of high-frequency dispersion reduces presence of red supportive high-frequency features and allows the model's learned low-frequency patterns (which it associates with the other class) to dominate. Interpretation: smooth, sustained plateaus (low-frequency-only) are more likely to be flagged atypical (blue) for the pointing class and cause misclassification.
pattern: Sample 5 (ID:5) pattern: True label = 1 (pointing). Sample 131 (ID:131) pattern: True label = 1. Model result: predicted = 0. Logits: [0.1736, -0.3976] show model tilting to class 0. The decisive pattern is the sustained plateau low-frequency signature (blue in SHAP) combined with the rise+return morphology that the model learned as gun-like.

Overall reflection on misclassification: in these boundary pointing examples the features that most push the model to predict the opposite class are (1) large-amplitude, sustained positive plateaus (long hold) and (2) a clear two-phase temporal morphology (rise, long hold, descent/undershoot). In the STFT this maps to concentrated low-frequency (0Hz) energy during the event. The SHAP heatmaps consistently mark the plateau low-frequency cells as blue (atypical for label 1), so the model down-weights typical baseline features (red) and up-weights the atypical sustained-energy signature — this imbalance is the core cause of misclassification in every sample above.

Comprehensive analysis and confirmation that the preliminary summary already covers the sample-specific boundary features (detailed reasoning):

Trend and baseline (early phase, t≈0–45): The trace remains a stable negative offset around -0.65 with only very small slow fluctuations (±0.02–0.05). In the STFT this corresponds to very-low-frequency / DC energy concentrated at the 0 Hz row but with low magnitude. The SHAP heatmap marks this early baseline predominantly with light-red at the 0 Hz / adjacent very-low-frequency rows — the model treats this baseline as typical supportive evidence for the pointing label. This is consistent with the preliminary summary and is not the cause of misclassification.

Onset / rapid rise (onset phase, t≈45–60): The signal shows a sharp upward slope beginning around time step ~45 and peaking by ~60, rising from roughly -0.65 to ~+1.9–2.1 (Δ ≈ 2.5–2.8 in this sample). The STFT shows a time-localized increase in energy concentrated at the lowest frequency bins while remaining narrow-band (little high-frequency spread). The SHAP heatmap in this rise window is mixed: some low-frequency cells show red and some show neutral-to-slight-blue. This mixed coloring indicates model ambiguity for the rapid rise: when the rise is relatively steep and large its contribution becomes atypical for pointing (blue patches) whereas milder rises are seen as typical (red). In Sample 5 the rise is fairly steep and contributes some blue SHAP weight — this partially reduces support for label 1.

Sustained plateau / hold (mid phase, t≈60–80): The signal remains at a high positive level about +2.05 for a prolonged window (~20 time steps). The STFT exhibits strong concentrated energy at the 0 Hz row (dominant DC/very-low-frequency energy) during this window. In the SHAP heatmap the same low-frequency cells during the plateau are predominantly blue, indicating that the model regards this sustained low-frequency elevation as atypical for pointing and more gun-like. This plateau is the primary atypical feature for label 1 in this sample and the main driver of the black-box model tipping toward class 0. The plateau's low-frequency dominance and long duration (hold) match precisely the misclassification cause described in the preliminary summary.

Descent and crossing (t≈80–95): The signal shows a moderate-to-sharp negative slope back through 0 and down to a negative trough. The STFT again concentrates energy at low frequencies during the descent. The SHAP marking here is mixed: low-frequency cells show small blue patches in the descent region but there are also light red cells just after the crossing. This mixed coloring indicates ambiguity: some aspects of the descent resemble the two-stroke gun-draw return (atypical for pointing), while other aspects remain consistent with pointing.

Negative undershoot / return valley (t≈95–115): A short negative trough around -0.7 to -0.8 appears, then the trace returns slowly to ~-0.55. STFT energy is low-frequency; SHAP shows light-red at the low-frequency bins around the trough for this sample, indicating the model can view this undershoot as somewhat typical for pointing. Because the trough depth is moderate and smooth (no broad jitter), it does not strongly push classification toward gun.

Frequency morphology and jitter (overall): Across the whole event the energy is narrow-band concentrated at DC/very-low-frequency rows; there is little high-frequency dispersion or jitter. The SHAP heatmap focuses on these very-low-frequency rows; absence of high-frequency supportive features means the model relies heavily on low-frequency patterns, allowing the plateau's atypical low-frequency signature to dominate.

Logits and model decision: The predicted label is 0 (gun) with logits [-0.0207, -0.1238], indicating only a mild margin favoring class 0. The SHAP heatmap shows that the plateau low-frequency cells are the strongest blue (atypical for pointing) contributors; combined with mixed/ambiguous coloring in the rise and descent, the plateau's atypical signature is sufficient to flip the decision. This matches the preliminary summary assertions: the long sustained high plateau (low-frequency DC energy) + the rise-hold-return morphology are the classification-boundary drivers.

Conclusion on omissions: All features that cause this sample to be a boundary / misclassified example (stable negative baseline, steep rise, long sustained high plateau dominated by 0 Hz energy, ambiguous descent, moderate undershoot, absence of high-frequency jitter) are already enumerated in the provided preliminary feature summary. No additional misclassification-causing features or patterns are missing for Sample 5. The preliminary summary correctly identifies the plateau low-frequency signature and rise–hold–return morphology as the decisive boundary features.
